Review title: John Carpenter presents an original Lovecraftian tale
Review_body: In the Mouth of Madness is an American psychological horror film from director John Carpenter. It serves as the third and final film in Carpenter's Apocalypse Trilogy of movies. The others being Prince of Darkness and The Thing. Starring Sam Neill, Julie Carmen, Jürgen Prochnow, David Warner and Charlton Heston. The film was distributed by New Line Pictures and released on December 10th, 1994 in Italy before being released in the US the following year.The story is told in a flashback. An insurance adjuster (Sam Neill) is investigating the disappearance of horror writer Sutter Cane. After his books seem to be having a strange effect on his readers. He goes with the writers editor (Julie Carmen) to look for the fictional town, Hobb's End. In hopes of finding the reclusive writer. They actually find the town and find themselves being written into the next best selling Sutter Cane book. Or, did they not exist until Cane wrote about them?The psychological elements are incorporated with a lot of care and respect for the genre. Carpenter did an amazing job delivering tension and anxiety in every scene. This is a perfect homage to Lovecraftian works, while also putting a finish on the Apocalypse Trilogy.Sam Neill goes off the rails with his performance. We watch this man have a mental-breakdown and it's awesome. His character, John Trent, is a sceptical insurance adjuster that travels to the seemingly fictional town of Hobbs End to find the horror novelist, Sutter Cane. It's An oddball locale to lose your mind in. A place full of tortured souls and creatures from beyond.The downside is the obvious financial limits that John Carpenter had to work with. The film was shot in Canada and for some reason some of the lines were poorly over-dubbed. It takes me out of the movie every time. I think the worst is Sutter Canes agent breaking a window and asking, "...do you read Sutter Cane?" I just don't like it.Although it has a few flaws, John Carpenter's Lovecraftian love-letter is definitely worth a watch. In the Mouth of Madness provides a lot of anxiety driving scenes that will keep you positioned on the edge of your seat for the entire viewing. I have seen this film multiple times now. But still get creeped out by the dreary location and doomed vibe. It's not a hard movie to find and is pretty common online. Check it out.

What can I say about this movie, The old horror movies are just fantastic, I love the old effects that they use and not only CGI. Even if it has some effects that are badly achieved, the movie itself is a really nice experience. The story is inspired by the books of H.P. Lovecraft with his cosmic horror represented in every frame of the movie. The performances are fine and the setting is immersived like it should be. Overall In the Mouth of Madness is a good movie and definitely is a must watch if you are an H.P. Lovecraft fan.

This is, in my opinion, the best horror movie of the 90's!  It has an incredible script by Michael De Luca and the direction of John Carpenter is top notch. Never knowing what is around the next corner and never liking what you find is what makes In The Mouth of Madness a very horrifying yet enjoyable 90 minutes.

I liked this movie for the same reason that I love reading H.P. Lovecraft: it's a cheesy but enjoyable psychological horror yarn. It can be contrived and melodramatic at times, just like Lovecraft's stories, but this is actually used positively in this film. The tongue-in-cheek approach, emphasized by Neill's transition from skeptic to raving lunatic, will make any pulp fiction reader smile knowingly.There aren't any real scares in this one, per se, but it does well enough in establishing a surreal, claustrophobic atmosphere that makes you wonder exactly where reality ends. When it's campy it's fun, but it also has its share of good horror scenes that can also make you think.After watching the horrible "Vampires," I had to watch this one again to make sure it was the same director, but Carpenter did, in fact, do a good job on this one. Jürgen Prochnow has a relatively small, but juicy part as the reclusive horror writer Cane, and the appearance of various Cthulhu-esque monsters seems to be Carpenter's way of paying tribute to HPL. Good one.

Review title: "Do you read Sutter Cane?" - the great Lovecraftian homage
Review_body: I think that this movie is the best and most faithful to the works of the late cosmic horror author H.P. Lovecraft not just in the appearance of the monsters and the plot ideas, but in the idea that we are all so small and insignificant to the horrible things that we have no knowledge of. There are a few flaws in it, but I don't let them get in the way of a great movie.The movie begins with John Trent (Sam Neill) being dragged into an insane asylum in a straitjacket, trying to tell the orderlies that he's not insane. He is visited by Dr. Wren (David Warner), who is trying to help get him out of there. When asked how he got to the hospital, Trent tells him about his job as a freelance insurance investigator and that it all started with the disappearance of Sutter Cane (Jürgen Prochnow). At the diner, Robbie (Bernie Casey), who runs the insurance company Trent worked at, is at a diner trying to convince him to start working for him and tells him that there's a claim that Sutter Cane is missing that cost millions. Suddenly, an axe-wielding maniac smashes the diner window and asks Trent, "Do you read Sutter Cane?" before he's shot to death by police. Later, Trent is told by Linda Styles (Julie Carmen) that Cane's books have a mentally scarring effect on his less stable readers. He discovers a couple nights later that Hobb's End, the town from many of Cane's novels is real, and starts to see the nightmarish truth behind the strange behavior of his readers ... and his own existence.Really creepy movie that deserves to have others similar to it, and a great homage to one of my favorite horror authors. My only complaint is Julie Carmen. I don't remember much about her in Fright Night Part II, but her acting in this movie was really bad. Still, it doesn't kill the movie, and towards the end, Trent says something that has haunted me for a long time: "Every species can smell its own extinction. The last ones left won't have a pretty time with it. In ten years, the human race will just be a bedtime story for the children, a myth. Nothing more." 10/10 (highly recommended for Lovecraft and horror fans)

In the Mouth of Madness is a brilliant movie in a Lovcraftian style. John Carpenter did an excellent job on this film, but he usually does with most films. All of his films have a very Lovecraft feel to it. If you're a Lovecraft geek (like me) see this film. You won't be disappointed. One of the most scary parts of the film is when Trent is running away from the monsters. But overall, the most scary aspect of this film is that you don't know what's fiction or reality. Even in the end... Take my advice and see it, preferably in the dark, where you don't know if a tentacle might come out from behind your closet door or maybe even under your bed...

Review title: Carpenter's surreal horror in a world of horror novels
Review_body: An insurance investigator is tasked with finding an author of famous horror novels, but the mystery is not easily solved when the novels themselves seem to be infecting the world.A horror film that borders more on the surreal. The film although a horror explores more the insecurities and distresses of man when faced with uncertainties and mystifying incidents. This film can be rather reality bending and can be placed alongside films from David Lynch.The film features some great acting especially from Sam Neill, who does some of his best work in this film, a real standout that is memorable. The great Charlton Heston also features in a small role. In the Mouth of Madness features some great practical effects, in the same vein as Carpenter's The Thing, and visuals that effectively demonstrates the surreal and reoccurring situations.In the Mouth of Madness has a unique plot that starts of quite strong with a mystery that keeps the viewer engaged, it might fall a bit in the middle, but as many Carpenter films do it ends strong.Recommend this to those who seek to watch a unique horror film or to those who are looking for something a bit Lynchian.

Once Neil is being interviewed about how he got there we see the film as told by his recollection of the past events that led up to him arriving there. Now this is where I got interested as it did a good job of setting up the premise and for the first 40 minutes or so it really is an interesting ride. There are a some nicely shot scenes and you do get a sense of eeriness and it is a little unsettling in parts but unfortunately the film runs out of steam fairly quickly and the end result was disappointing as the film is too all over the place and disjointed by the time the credits roll. The acting on the whole wasn't too great either, I thought Sam Neil did a good enough job but the supporting cast were pretty poor as were some of the special effects. It's a film that had potential but ultimately winds up being too clever for it's own good. 5/10

I consider this movie as the best, the most intelligent and the most shocking horror film of the decade! Carpenter pursuits his career with a coherency seldom met at the American directors; his obsessions and preferences become an ars poetica, shaping more elaborate forms. Carpenter's horror touches us deep inside not by what we are shown, but by what we are suggested to believe. Just like many pop and movie stars do nowadays, Sutter Cane has a whole world down on its knees. This evil wants reduction to sameness, wants to make the audiences all around the world think the same, be the same, act the same. Only then is Cane, as he proclaims, God. The entire horror phenomenon is pointed at and -in a way- mocked at, because the bad influence of horror products is revealed fully.A continual and dark nightmare, the movie proves to be a skilled postmodernistic approach to H.P. Lovecraft's writings, not only in the atmosphere, but also in the visualisation and plot. Sam Neill is flawless as detective John Trent and Julie Carmen-comfortable in her part. The writer is the German actor Jurgen Prochnow who brings a necessary European flavour to the character. Extremely well-made visual effects (the scene where Cane tears himself like a page is impressive) and haunting score. Well done, John Carpenter!

"I'm sorry about the balls! It was a lucky shot, that's all!" Sam Neill's strained delivery of this line managed to illicit an early chuckle. As In the Mouth of Madness continued, I began to notice that this lament applied to the entirety of the proceedings. Any impact, testicular or otherwise, that the film had seemed to be down to "a lucky shot" rather than crafted direction.John Carpenter is a director with a somewhat chequered record. Responsible for classics such as Assault on Precinct 13 (1976), Halloween (1978) and The Thing (1982), Carpenter also has the dubious distinction of helming misfires like Ghosts of Mars (2001), Escape from L.A. (1996) and Big Trouble in Little China (1986). In the Mouth of Madness falls somewhere muddy in between the extremes.Penned by studio executive and Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare (1991) author Michael De Luca, the film plays like a TV movie mystery with a H.P. Lovecraft pre-occupation. Sam Neill plays John Trent, a seemingly pre-eminent freelance insurance claims investigator, hired by a publisher to locate their missing star talent, Sutter Cane, played Jurgen Prochnow. Cane is a ubiquitous horror writer, one of those literally 'big names' who's moniker dwarfs the title on the cover. Apparently his works have a profoundly disquieting affect on the less mentally stable members of his vast fan base, and the anticipation for his latest volume is at a violent fever pitch. In what is probably the film's most successful scene, even Cane's agent succumbs to the hysteria in time tested axe wielding fashion. The ever sceptical Trent is eventually dispatched to a possibly non-existent little corner of New England, along with the horribly stilted Julie Carmen playing Cane's editor, Linda Styles. The spookiness then begins in earnest, is it all a publicity stunt? Has Cane gone mad? Can Carpenter manage to hold things together long enough for us to care? In the Mouth of Madness clearly has lofty ambitions. The framing device initially seems hackneyed but grows in to almost David Lynch territory. H.P. Lovecraft's material, although not directly adapted here, is notoriously difficult to bring to the screen, and has been unsuccessfully relied upon to bring the bulk of the scares. My ultimate impression is that neither De Luca nor Carpenter have a firm enough grasp on the material to make a coherent or entertaining film.My expectations of the film were immediately lowered by the horribly clichéd heavy rock opening music. I think this interview extract (originally from Violet Veil magazine) humorously demonstrates just how far of the mark Carpenter's judgement was with this film: Interviewer: "In the Mouth lightly satirised the horror genre, but did you also do that with the music? The opening number has a very heavy metal feel" JC: "What you do when you're screening for audiences you put temporary music on, when you don't have it done. And we put on Metallica's 'Enter Sandman' and the whole audience, their heads were bobbing and I said 'You know what, why don't we start the movie with something like that?' So one of my pals Dave Davies (the lead guitarist from the Kinks) wrote the song. It was a great way to get the movie going, it gets you cranked, it gets you going!" The fact Carpenter thought a limp, public domain doppelganger track would have a similar affect to the biggest ever metal band's most famous song pretty much sums up the level of competence, or lack thereof, on show. The genre references and instances of dark humour are too few and far between for the film to be considered a send up, and the horror is far too anaemic for it be straight. The globally poor standard of acting on show does little to help matters. Horror fans may find the less usual elements and Lovecraft flavour worth watching for, less passionate viewers should dust off a copy of Halloween, The Thing, or even Prince of Darkness (1987) before resorting to slumming it in the mouth of mediocrity.

Good psychological horror film, dreamlike, etc. It won't stay on my retina, but you can see it, it's interesting. Well run, well filmed, well acted. It's not my style, the Lovecraftian style, very difficult to bring to the screen, but it turned out well, popcorn and a good time.

Unsettling, intelligent, witty and thought-provoking. John Carpenter's 1994 flim in The Mouth of Madness takes a look at the thin line between reality and fiction, as it points the finger back at the viewer, asking us how real the worlds and realities we consume in our media really are.Insurance Claims investigator (who comes across more like a detective) John Trent (Sam Neil) goes on the hunt for renowned horror author Sutter Cane (Jürgen Prochnow) after he disappears under mysterious circumstances. Cane's editor, Linda Styles (Julie Carmen) joins him as the lines between what is real and isn't distort beyond comprehension.A flim that ages very well, Sam Neil is a very likeable character who holds the reins well throughout, capturing the disintegration of Trent's mind masterfully. I wasn't too keen on Julie Carmen's performance as it felt like she was phoning it in most of the time, spare a couple of scenes. Jürgen Prochnow as Cane does a really good job at making Cane a enigma of sorts as we never get a clear reading of how Cane is taking the events of the movie.Ultimately, In The Mouth of Madness is a great pulpy, cosmic horror joyride with hints of black comedy sprinkled throughout to keep the peace that is a timeless classic worth rewatching.

Review title: If you like Lovecraft, Hirohiko Araki or just fantasy in general you will love this
Review_body:
I'm not a big fan of horror genre. I actually tend to avoid it because I am easily scared, and I don't like being scared, but I love Lovecraft because for me his stories and his imagination are very evocative and intriguing and very fascinating too, and I also love Araki's work because I just love the bizarre, and this movie is 100% Lovecraft except Lovecraft has never been that bizarre, completely messed up, absurd and plain crazy. This movie is 200% madness, at firts it seems normal and maybe a bit boring too (it is on purpose, of course) but things escalate really quickly and this movie becomes the funniest and wildest rollercoaster ride in the territory of fantasy and darkness.
I think that this movie is not too scary, but maybe it is just because I really hate reality, and reality is the real "victim" in this movie.
Watching the movie it is clear that the main chasracter will never be in real danger... well, at least his body is not. It is the whole world around him that gets completely twisted, destroyed and blown up during the entire movie until in the end he don't even know "what" he or any other human being in the "real" world is, and for me this feels more intriguing and entertaining than scary.
In my opinion the gore is rather tame too, I usually cannot stand gore and violence but there is not so much that makes the movie too hard to watch in my opinion.
Some scenes are actually creepy, some of them became even creepier after I watched the movie several times, but overall in my opinion this movie is just very enjoyable, and every scene that was creepy also somehow felt cool at the same time, so cool that it ends up being really enjoyable.
I know that many horror fans like this movie too, but I write this review for people like me who are not into horror that much but love fantasy, love weird stuff, and don't like reality that much, I suggest you to give this movie a try because in my opinion you could really love it. If you are not sure maybe try to read a few stories by Lovecraft first: if you feel comfortable reading them then definitely watch this because I think that you will love it.

Review title: Is it real....or is it madness?
Review_body: This was one of the first movies to really scare me since I saw Alien when I was 6 years old. The movie leaves you wondering when events are actually happening to Trent, and which are being concocted in the twisted mind of Sutter Cane.  The acting was very good, save a less-than-fabulous perfomance from actress Julie Carmen.  Scenes like the boy on the bike, old woman and her husband, and (even more so) the ever changing scenery, will give you goose bumps for hours after the movie ends.  One of Carpenter's best!

Review title: The best HP Lovecraft film done to date
Review_body: In The Mouth Of Madness is without a doubt the best Lovecraftian movie ever made, even though it is an original script not taken directly from one of his works. There are a number of references to Stephen King in this film, but King himself admits to a deep love of all things Lovecraft; and the writer in the film, Sutter Kane, is closer to Charles Dexter Ward than Stephen King.New England settings, different dimensions, what you don't see is what will kill you (and thereby all of us), and the return of elder gods (or eldritch gods if you prefer) to reclaim this plane and planet as their own are all central parts of the stories and novels of HP Lovecraft. The scriptwriter does a wonderful job of combining so many elements of the Cthulhu mythos without ever actually referring to any of them as such.The third installment in Carpenter's apocalypse trilogy. The end of the world is coming. Soon! And we cannot stop it.

I think its safe to say that a full appreciation of this film requires some understanding of 1920's horror writer H.P. Lovecraft. Lovecraft is actually credited by Carpenter as the inspiration for In The Mouth of Madness, not to mention several of his other films. As a stand alone film, I find the plot to be bizarre and incomprehensible, but as an elucidation of Lovecraft's vision it was right on the mark.Order and sanity were not requisite components of Lovecraft's fiction, and you won't find them in this film either. The enduring suspicion throughout is that humans may be merely the temporal pawns of "the old ones;" god-like beings that hilariously delude humans into worshipping them. Also like Lovecraft's work, there is a serious thread of humor running through the film. Underlying the gore and confusion, there is a comical, nearly academic compulsion to examine existential questions. The incongruous mix of profundity and silliness makes this movie unbalancing and more than a little funny. The absurdity, like the visceral horror, is simply something that viewer will have to take at face value.

If anyone's read any Lovecraft (and loved it), they would be proud of Carpenter's "In the Mouth of Madness". It's one of the best horror movies I've ever seen and Carpenter's best film. I believe true horror is knowing you're going mad... this movie captures Lovecraft's world of madness perfectly.

Review title: Still in my top 5 worst movies I have ever watched!
Review_body: There are people that actually liked this dumpster fire? I do not do reviews, but when I saw that this movie had over 7 stars I felt the need to warn people. This movie was an utter bomb. It lost money, (by a lot) and while that isn't enough to prove its a bad movie, it should be enough to get people wondering why it bombed so badly. It is the only movie I have ever seen at a theater where the entire audience groaned at the ending. Everyone continued griping and complaining about it all the way out of the building. It is also the only movie I have ever seen in a theater that was pulled in less than a week. There is a strong contingent (especially among horror fans) that seem to enjoy horrible endings simply because they are horrible, from the positive postings on this movie it appears that all of them fit into that category. If you are not one of them I strongly suggest you find something more entertaining to do, such as gouging your eyeballs out with a drill.

Review title: Freaked me out from start to finish
Review_body: In The Mouth of Madness is definitely the most disturbing film I have ever seen Sam Neill in, and easily the best. This is one of the few times when a movie has really stuck in my head for days after and freaked me out all the way from start to finish.Despite the cheap-looking monsters, John Carpenter uses this to his advantage, and the movie is even nastier thanks to it. The script is intelligent and the acting brilliant, so I really can't think of a bad thing to say about it. The ending literally made me shiver, and although I didn't think any of the film was actually scary, it definitely plays with your head and gives you a chill.I've only watched it once as it really is one of those films you can only see once, but I strongly recommend it, especially if you can forgive the cheap production. This is the only film I've given a 10 star to so far, and for good reasons. The best horror I've ever seen, and easily one my favourite films.

This movie felt like a mix of The Shining and HP Lovecraft, and it truly got under my skin! Sam Neill is excellent as a private investigator that is looking into the disappearance of a famour horror writer and is worth the price of admission alone.I was honestly shocked that I don't hear much about this film, it definitely flew under my radar so I would recommend any horror or Carpenter fans to give this one a shot!

In the Mouth of Madness is a truly scary movie.  The basic idea is that a horror writer, Sutter Kane, is making his fans crazy.  As the movie progresses, we find that his books are acutually true.  Surprisingly, most people haven't heard of this movie but I highly recommend it.  Sam Neil gives one of the better performances of his career and John Carpenter once again delivers the scares and chills in this movie.

Review title: Now it seems like an un-original premise
Review_body: In the year 2000, we have lived through the enormous blockbuster The Matrix, and its subsequent rip-offs such as the 13th floor. Both films make us want to question reality. The Matrix throws it in your face and makes you eat it for breakfast. In the Mouth of Madness is a little more subtle. It lets you do a little thinking on your own, and the result is a much more terrifying film. I saw the movie 3 years ago and it frightened me, and i don't find movies frightening very often. Then, i just bought the DVD a watched it again and realized how terrifying it really is. But this time I started to laugh with Trent. It's all you can do at that point, right? Are you somebody's character? Are you meant to interact with the people you know because it's been scripted? What does such knowledge mean? Who controls your world? Do you have a world? This is reality. This is not reality. This is the mouth of madness.

gosh, this is the worst film i've seen since i rented 'the swarm!' absolutely no surprises to this movie ... after you've seen the first 5 minutes, you basically know where the rest of the movie is headed. the story is illogical even for a horror film and keeps changing its 'rules' as it goes along. the shame is that such fine actors like sam neill (who does remarkably well under the circumstances), david warner, and john glover are wasted so shamelessly. cheesy dialogue too. only a knowingly throwaway bit from charlton heston & sam neill's nonchalant performance prevent me from giving this movie a 1. just rent 'videodrome' or 'lost highway' if you want to see this sort of thing done right.

The first time I watched it, I was still a youngster and I got scared. Not because of the monsters, but because of the psychological creepiness. Every movie that deals with the human psyche, if it is done successfully, can cause that (see Jacob's Ladder). But this movie has something different going on here and can only be observed if you see the patterns emerging. This is a movie about the nature of reality. It could be seen like a horror interpretation of Plato's Cave analogy. The main character seems trapped into this reality, forced unto him by the Godlike powers of the Writer. In the scene inside the church where they talk, Sutter Cane tells him that the only thing necessary for something to become reality is belief. Even if there is denial and resistance to it, it is still a belief. In other words, we see the struggle of a man, who feels trapped into a horrifying novel, determined by forces outside of him. He wants to get out, but he can't and the reason is belief. The ending seems mysterious, but it closes the movie with the right way. Going into the theater, as a guest and watching the movie of his life. He cries and then he laughs. He realized that everything was in his head. Just a movie playing and the stronger he believed in it, the more real it became. Of course, there is subtle humor from everyone involved and can be seen in their performances. And the Lovecraftian references, (see monsters and the deterministic nature of one's life), just make it more enjoyable. A highly entertaining horror movie, that pays tribute to the creators of such books and movies but with an underlying philosophical aspect. Watch it!

Review title: One of Carpenter's most underrated films!
Review_body: Personally, I think this movie was excellent. John carpenter has put together one of his most interesting, and unique films in his career that rarely gets the credit it deserves. Think of this movie like a twisted version of the matrix for horror geeks such as myself. This movie asks the question is reality what it seems, or are we all just pawns in the hands of a messed up creator, or author for that matter.Sam Neil plays John Trent. A hired investigator on a hunt for the best selling horror novelists known as Sutter Cane played by Jurgen Prochnow. As Trent comes closer and closer to finding Cane, horrible, and grotesque things start to happen, and reality just seems to fall apart. His search leads him to a place called Hobbs End, a place surprisingly not on any map, with good reason, because no one would want to live in a place like that, trust me. When Trent finally discovers his real reason for existing, his world and yours will be completely turned upside down. Big ups to John Carpenter on this fine piece of work.
Damn straight masterpiece. One of the best films of the senturies. Underated and overlooked but I would sugest that you give it a try. This is John at his best.

Review title: Mutant axe wielding sub humans..... Im in!
Review_body: Being a big fan of John Carpenter's Movies, my opinion on this particular title could be deemed as being biased. However I sincerely enjoyed this dark, comic and sometimes disturbing little gem. The plot was done in the usual Carpenter-esquire trademark with it's uglier than life anti-heroes trying to survive in an inhospitable environment whilst occasionally spitting out some witty if somewhat corny one-liners. The camera work is what to be expected from the director as is the trademark music that always adds that little extra atmosphere to his movies. The one thing that makes In the Mouth of Madness unique to John Carpenter's other films is the connection to a certain Lovecraft Mythos. This film has a strong sub plot of the weakness of the protagonist's sanity. You have your freaky town with its dark secrets and mutating indigenous population and not to mention the tonnes of tentacles thrown into the mix. All in all I really enjoyed the movie, but if you disagree then try a Barbera Streisand flick, that's sure to scare you!

Review title: Lovecraft has never been better represented than this!

Trivia IN THE MOUTH OF MADNESS is a pun on Lovecraft's AT THE MOUNTAINS OF MADNESS. Great film, recommended. Cthulhu apocalypse.

Review title: A very good movie, often overlooked
Review_body: In the Mouth of Madness may (and at times, does) seem like just another Lovecraft-inspired, low-budget movie, but in reality it possesses some characteristics which really set it apart.The story revolves around John Trent, an insurance claims investigator (played by Sam Neill) who is hired to find Sutter Cane (Jürgen Prochnow), a famous horror writer who disappeared, and the strange things happening around Trent while he looks for Cane.I don't want to give away any important parts of the movie (but I probably will, anyway), but some things make this movie stand apart from other horror movies: The plot is actually very well-built, with many little loops and twists. The audience, just as Trent, doesn't really know what exactly is going on or where the next twist will come from. There are many cross-references to other movies and books and, the best part, to the movie itself.Three of the actors – Sam Neill, Jürgen Prochnow and the celebrated Charlton Heston as the owner of the publishing house – simply save the movie, even through some odd sentences in the script (though the odd sentences are there for a reason, which I'll talk about later on, they do sound a little forced). Unfortunately, that only makes Julie Carmen look worse as Linda Styles, the editor who accompanies Trent from about the middle of the movie. Her acting could be a little worse, I suppose, but it would take some effort on her part.The special effects team did a good job, in general, I think. Considering we're talking about 1994, with a relatively low budget, portraying "horrors beyond imagining", any team has a hard time convincing the audience that anything is really monstrous. The flashed pictures are good enough, but the long takes, especially when the light is not so low, fail to cause any impression of fear. The human deformities, however, look real enough to cause some discomfort.Photography is quite good, actually, with different camera takes helping the movie come along. There are no expensive shots, like aerial ones, but we've got top down shots that work very well, and shots that put the viewer in the scene, as it were. View changes are also used to very good effect, but the ones involving Julie Carmen lose some oomph because of her acting. But don't expect any unusual scares – the boogiemen are all there, at exactly the time you expect, with appropriate sound effects, just as expected.But the best thing about this movie, in my opinion, are the cross-references and little jokes. You get quotes and references to Lovecraft, references to Stephen King (including Hobb's End, a town modeled on his own Castle Rock – if you know King, you know Castle Rock), the weird doctor, the Carpenter song playing ("We've only just begun", later also used by Stephen King in 1408, for a different effect), the line "Sorry about the balls – it was a lucky shot" and many others. Final credits also deserve mention: "Human interaction was monitored by the Inter Planetary Psychiatric Association. The body count was high, the casualties are heavy." As I said before, some lines sound awkward, and that's because they were taken from or inspired by Lovecraft's writing. I enjoy reading Lovecraft very much, but he tends to be very verbose, and his characters' conversations never sound natural.All in all, this is a very good movie, and will be great entertainment, especially for the dedicated horror fans, who will have a good time deciphering the references.

Review title: Sic Transit Gloria Mundi (et sic de similibus)
Review_body: This film carries a hidden meaning and message that is far too abstruse, difficult, and complex, for most to fully comprehend. A must see for any adherent to aesthetics: the science of the beautiful; and the doctrines of taste, who truly seeks to know what's really "wrong with this picture".The power of suggestion, a dynamic that is already at work, and most effectively in force in this world, is the real underlying plot, or back story here; and one that is so ingeniously conceived, and well hidden, that it is almost as completely invisible to the casual observer as it's (so-called) real-life counterpart.The evidence of which being most clearly exemplified through any number of the various different viewers comments upon the film.The film itself is much less about the director John Carpenter, than it is about the writer and executive producer Michael De Luca. A man of many considerable means himself, who is not only the one who really truly see's here, but the real"ghost-in-the-machine", or man behind the curtain, as well.The very title of the film is an alliteration to"from out of the mouths of babes", and infralapsarianism; both of which being reflective of such recondite and esoteric principles as which can only be understood by "following the white rabbit", and employing the process of "syntactic bootstrapping", by carrying out such propositions as "reality is only what people tell us it is", and "the problem with religion is that nobody really believes it", to their ultimate conclusions. Do this, and perhaps you too will be able to see.If this movie doesn't quite literally scare the hell out of you, then you just might very well be, one of "them".

It's entertainning, but in a very lower level from Lovecraft

There were no really horrifying monsters. Whoever reads the book the story becomes about them. John Trent was the whole story, but only for John Trent. If David Moody had read it, it would then be about David Moody, and that would be his name under the title. That's how the people went insane.The monsters are just a point to help drive you mad. Imagine you are being chased by monsters and you are just about to get away but you bump into a police officer and he try's to keep you from running off. Well that officer is now a threat to you because there are monsters after you and you have get away. So you attack maybe even kill the cop just to get away. Problem is there were no monsters. Only in you mind were they real. Thats what makes you crazy. Now you are insane to the public. Though if everyone reads the book, then insanity is real and everyone else are the truly afflicted because the can't see the monster that could be right behind them. That is the genius and I believe the point of this film. Wonderfully introspective. You have every right to disagree though.
